1. First, let's update `gre-vs-gmat.mdx`:

---

_****_

```diff
  ---
  
- ### GMAT vs GRE 비교
- 
- #### 1. 목적 및 활용
- - **GMAT**: 경영대학원(MBA) 입학에 초점을 맞추어 설계된 시험으로, 리더십 및 비즈니스 관련 기술을 평가함.
- - **GRE**: 더 넓은 범위의 대학원 과정(석사 및 박사) 입학을 목표로 하며, 인문학, 과학, 공학, 사회과학 등 다양한 분야에서 사용됨.
- 
- #### 2. 시험 비용
- - **GMAT**: 약 $275로 GRE보다 비쌈.
- - **GRE**: 약 $220로 GMAT보다 상대적으로 저렴함.
- 
- #### 3. 점수 유효기간
- - GMAT과 GRE 모두 **점수 유효기간은 5년**으로 동일함.
- 
- #### 4. 시험 길이 및 형식
- - **GMAT**: 총 시험 시간은 약 3시간 7분, **Computer Adaptive Test(CAT)** 방식으로 진행되며, 답변에 따라 다음 문제가 조정됨.
- - **GRE**: 총 시험 시간은 약 3시간 45분, 섹션별 난이도가 조정되는 **Section Adaptive Test** 방식으로 진행됨.
- 
- #### 5. 대학원 입학에서의 선호도
- - **GMAT**: 대부분의 MBA 프로그램에서 GMAT 점수를 요구하거나 우선적으로 고려함.
- - **GRE**: MBA 외에도 다양한 분야의 대학원 과정에 적합하며, 비즈니스 스쿨에서도 수용 가능.
- 
- #### 6. 시험 준비의 난이도
- - **GMAT**: 수리 부분은 논리적 추론을 기반으로 하며, 복잡한 문제들이 출제됨.
- - **GRE**: 수리 부분은 상대적으로 간단하지만, 언어적 문제(Text Completion, Sentence Equivalence 등)가 고난이도 단어를 포함하여 어려움을 줄 수 있음.
- 
- #### 7. 재시험 정책
- - **GMAT**: 
-   - 12개월 동안 최대 **5회 응시 가능**.
-   - 평생 최대 **8회 응시 제한**.
- - **GRE**:
-   - **21일 간격**으로 최대 5회 응시 가능.
-   - 응시 횟수에 제한 없음.
- 
- #### 8. 스코어 리포팅
- - **GMAT**: 최근 점수만 제출하거나 선택적으로 보고 가능.
- - **GRE**: 여러 시험 중 가장 좋은 점수를 선택적으로 제출할 수 있는 **ScoreSelect** 기능 제공.
- 
- #### 9. 커리어 플랜
- - **GMAT**: 비즈니스, 금융, 컨설팅과 같은 분야에서 높은 평가 가능.
- - **GRE**: 경영학 외에도 과학, 기술, 예술 분야로 진출하려는 학생들에게 적합.
+ <div x-data>
+   <template x-if="$store.language !== 'ko'">
+     <div class="en-content">
+       <h3>GMAT vs GRE Comparison</h3>
+ 
+       <h4>1. Purpose and Usage</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Designed specifically for business school (MBA) admissions, evaluating leadership and business-related skills.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Used for a broader range of graduate programs (Masters and PhD), accepted in humanities, sciences, engineering, and social sciences.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>2. Test Fees</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Approximately $275, more expensive than GRE.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Approximately $220, relatively cheaper than GMAT.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>3. Score Validity</h4>
+       <p>Both GMAT and GRE scores are valid for <strong>5 years</strong>.</p>
+ 
+       <h4>4. Test Length and Format</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Total test time is about 3 hours 7 minutes, uses <strong>Computer Adaptive Test (CAT)</strong> format where questions adjust based on answers.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Total test time is about 3 hours 45 minutes, uses <strong>Section Adaptive Test</strong> format where section difficulty adjusts.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>5. Graduate School Preferences</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Most MBA programs require or prefer GMAT scores.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Suitable for various graduate programs and accepted by business schools.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>6. Test Preparation Difficulty</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Quantitative section based on logical reasoning with complex problems.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Quantitative section relatively simpler, but verbal problems (Text Completion, Sentence Equivalence) can be challenging due to advanced vocabulary.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>7. Retake Policy</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>:
+           <ul>
+             <li>Maximum <strong>5 attempts</strong> within 12 months.</li>
+             <li>Lifetime limit of <strong>8 attempts</strong>.</li>
+           </ul>
+         </li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>:
+           <ul>
+             <li>Can retake every <strong>21 days</strong>.</li>
+             <li>No lifetime limit on attempts.</li>
+           </ul>
+         </li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>8. Score Reporting</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Can submit only recent scores or select specific scores.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Offers <strong>ScoreSelect</strong> option to submit best scores from multiple attempts.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>9. Career Plans</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Highly valued in business, finance, and consulting fields.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Suitable for students pursuing careers in science, technology, arts beyond business.</li>
+       </ul>
+     </div>
+   </template>
+ 
+   <template x-if="$store.language === 'ko'">
+     <div class="ko-content">
+       <h3>GMAT vs GRE 비교</h3>
+ 
+       <h4>1. 목적 및 활용</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 경영대학원(MBA) 입학에 초점을 맞추어 설계된 시험으로, 리더십 및 비즈니스 관련 기술을 평가함.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 더 넓은 범위의 대학원 과정(석사 및 박사) 입학을 목표로 하며, 인문학, 과학, 공학, 사회과학 등 다양한 분야에서 사용됨.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>2. 시험 비용</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 약 $275로 GRE보다 비쌈.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 약 $220로 GMAT보다 상대적으로 저렴함.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>3. 점수 유효기간</h4>
+       <p>GMAT과 GRE 모두 <strong>점수 유효기간은 5년</strong>으로 동일함.</p>
+ 
+       <h4>4. 시험 길이 및 형식</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 총 시험 시간은 약 3시간 7분, <strong>Computer Adaptive Test(CAT)</strong> 방식으로 진행되며, 답변에 따라 다음 문제가 조정됨.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 총 시험 시간은 약 3시간 45분, 섹션별 난이도가 조정되는 <strong>Section Adaptive Test</strong> 방식으로 진행됨.</li>
+       </ul>

+       </ul>

+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 수리 부분은 논리적 추론을 기반으로 하며, 복잡한 문제들이 출제됨.</li>
+         <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 수리 부분은 상대적으로 간단하지만, 언어적 문제(Text Completion, Sentence Equivalence 등)가 고난이도 단어를 포함하여 어려움을 줄 수 있음.</li>
+       </ul>

+       <ul>
+         <li><strong>GMAT</strong>:
+           <ul>
+             <li>12개월 동안 최대 <strong>5회 응시 가능</strong>.</li>
+             <li>평생 최대 <strong>8회 응시 제한</strong>.</li>

_****_



Now let's update `sat-vs-act.mdx`:

---

_****_

```diff
  ---
  
- ### SAT와 ACT 추가 비교 포인트
- 
- #### 1. 시험 난이도
- - SAT는 문제당 시간을 더 넉넉히 주는 편이므로, 깊이 있는 사고와 세밀한 문제 해결 능력을 요구합니다.
- - ACT는 더 많은 문제를 더 짧은 시간 안에 풀어야 하므로, 속도와 정확성이 중요합니다.
- 
- #### 2. 점수 환산
- - SAT 점수는 총 1600점 만점으로, 대학에서 요구하는 기준 점수는 보통 1200~1400점 이상입니다.
- - ACT 점수는 36점 만점이며, 경쟁력 있는 점수는 보통 28~34점입니다.
- 
- #### 3. 대학별 요구
- 미국 대학 대부분은 SAT와 ACT를 모두 수용하며, 특정 시험을 선호하지 않습니다. 그러나 일부 대학에서는 ACT의 과학 섹션을 통해 STEM(과학, 기술, 공학, 수학) 분야의 적합성을 더 자세히 평가하기도 합니다.
- 
- #### 4. 수학 섹션 차이
- - SAT 수학은 대수학과 데이터 분석에 더 중점을 둡니다.
- - ACT 수학은 삼각함수와 고등수학을 포함하며, 고급 수학 지식이 더 요구될 수 있습니다.
- 
- #### 5. 포맷 및 디지털화
- - SAT는 점점 디지털 포맷으로 전환 중이며, 시험 경험이 간소화되고 있습니다.
- - ACT는 현재 대부분의 학생이 여전히 종이 시험으로 치르고 있으며, 디지털 시험은 선택 사항입니다.
- 
- #### 6. 시험 준비 자료와 접근성
- - SAT는 Khan Academy와 협력하여 학생들에게 무료 온라인 학습 자료를 제공합니다.
- - ACT는 자체 온라인 연습 플랫폼과 다양한 학습 자료를 유료로 제공합니다.
- 
- #### 7. 국제적인 인지도
- - SAT는 국제적으로 더 널리 알려져 있으며, 특히 비영어권 국가에서 많이 선택됩니다.
- - ACT는 미국 내에서 주로 선택되며, 미국 중서부와 남부 지역에서 특히 선호됩니다.
- 
- #### 8. 논리적 사고와 과학적 분석
- - SAT는 전반적인 읽기, 쓰기, 수학을 통해 논리적 사고 능력을 평가합니다.
- - ACT는 별도의 과학 섹션을 통해 실질적인 데이터 분석과 과학적 사고를 요구합니다.
- 
- #### 9. 특정 시험 전략
- SAT는 단답형 문제와 다지문 독해가 많은 반면, ACT는 비교적 간단한 문제들이 빠르게 출제됩니다. 이는 전략적인 시험 준비를 요구합니다.
+ <div x-data>
+   <template x-if="$store.language !== 'ko'">
+     <div class="en-content">
+       <h3>Additional SAT vs ACT Comparison Points</h3>
+ 
+       <h4>1. Test Difficulty</h4>
+       <p>SAT allows more time per question, requiring deeper thinking and detailed problem-solving skills. ACT requires solving more questions in less time, emphasizing speed and accuracy.</p>
+ 
+       <h4>2. Score Conversion</h4>
+       <p>SAT scores range up to 1600 points, with competitive scores typically being 1200-1400 or higher. ACT scores go up to 36 points, with competitive scores typically ranging from 28-34.</p>
+ 
+       <h4>3. University Requirements</h4>
+       <p>Most U.S. universities accept both SAT and ACT without preference. However, some universities may use the ACT's science section to evaluate STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) aptitude more thoroughly.</p>
+ 
+       <h4>4. Math Section Differences</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT math focuses more on algebra and data analysis.</li>
+         <li>ACT math includes trigonometry and advanced mathematics, potentially requiring more advanced math knowledge.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>5. Format and Digitalization</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT is increasingly transitioning to digital format, streamlining the testing experience.</li>
+         <li>ACT is still primarily taken on paper by most students, with digital testing as an option.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>6. Test Prep Materials and Accessibility</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT partners with Khan Academy to provide free online study materials.</li>
+         <li>ACT offers its own online practice platform and various study materials for a fee.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>7. International Recognition</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT is more widely recognized internationally, especially in non-English speaking countries.</li>
+         <li>ACT is primarily chosen within the United States, particularly in the Midwest and Southern regions.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>8. Logical Thinking and Scientific Analysis</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT evaluates logical thinking through reading, writing, and math.</li>
+         <li>ACT requires practical data analysis and scientific thinking through its dedicated science section.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>9. Test Strategy</h4>
+       <p>SAT features more short-answer questions and multi-passage reading comprehension, while ACT presents relatively straightforward questions at a faster pace. This requires different strategic approaches to test preparation.</p>
+     </div>
+   </template>
+ 
+   <template x-if="$store.language === 'ko'">
+     <div class="ko-content">
+       <h3>SAT와 ACT 추가 비교 포인트</h3>
+ 
+       <h4>1. 시험 난이도</h4>
+       <p>SAT는 문제당 시간을 더 넉넉히 주는 편이므로, 깊이 있는 사고와 세밀한 문제 해결 능력을 요구합니다. ACT는 더 많은 문제를 더 짧은 시간 안에 풀어야 하므로, 속도와 정확성이 중요합니다.</p>
+ 
+       <h4>2. 점수 환산</h4>
+       <p>SAT 점수는 총 1600점 만점으로, 대학에서 요구하는 기준 점수는 보통 1200~1400점 이상입니다. ACT 점수는 36점 만점이며, 경쟁력 있는 점수는 보통 28~34점입니다.</p>
+ 
+       <h4>3. 대학별 요구</h4>
+       <p>미국 대학 대부분은 SAT와 ACT를 모두 수용하며, 특정 시험을 선호하지 않습니다. 그러나 일부 대학에서는 ACT의 과학 섹션을 통해 STEM(과학, 기술, 공학, 수학) 분야의 적합성을 더 자세히 평가하기도 합니다.</p>
+ 
+       <h4>4. 수학 섹션 차이</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT 수학은 대수학과 데이터 분석에 더 중점을 둡니다.</li>
+         <li>ACT 수학은 삼각함수와 고등수학을 포함하며, 고급 수학 지식이 더 요구될 수 있습니다.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>5. 포맷 및 디지털화</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT는 점점 디지털 포맷으로 전환 중이며, 시험 경험이 간소화되고 있습니다.</li>
+         <li>ACT는 현재 대부분의 학생이 여전히 종이 시험으로 치르고 있으며, 디지털 시험은 선택 사항입니다.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>6. 시험 준비 자료와 접근성</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT는 Khan Academy와 협력하여 학생들에게 무료 온라인 학습 자료를 제공합니다.</li>
+         <li>ACT는 자체 온라인 연습 플랫폼과 다양한 학습 자료를 유료로 제공합니다.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>7. 국제적인 인지도</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT는 국제적으로 더 널리 알려져 있으며, 특히 비영어권 국가에서 많이 선택됩니다.</li>
+         <li>ACT는 미국 내에서 주로 선택되며, 미국 중서부와 남부 지역에서 특히 선호됩니다.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>8. 논리적 사고와 과학적 분석</h4>
+       <ul>
+         <li>SAT는 전반적인 읽기, 쓰기, 수학을 통해 논리적 사고 능력을 평가합니다.</li>
+         <li>ACT는 별도의 과학 섹션을 통해 실질적인 데이터 분석과 과학적 사고를 요구합니다.</li>
+       </ul>
+ 
+       <h4>9. 특정 시험 전략</h4>
+       <p>SAT는 단답형 문제와 다지문 독해가 많은 반면, ACT는 비교적 간단한 문제들이 빠르게 출제됩니다. 이는 전략적인 시험 준비를 요구합니다.</p>
+     </div>
+   </template>
+ </div>
```

---

_****_



Now let's update `college-level-examination-program.mdx`:

---

_****_

```diff
  ---
  
+ <div x-data>
+   <template x-if="$store.language !== 'ko'">
+     <div class="en-content">
+       <p>
+         CLEP (College-Level Examination Program) is a testing program that can substitute for U.S. college education. It helps students demonstrate their academic abilities required for college courses and earn college credits. Through CLEP exams, students can save both time and money.
+       </p>
+ 
+       <p>
+         Since first offering 10 exams in 1967, CLEP now offers 34 subject exams. Students aged 18-22, high school graduates, and adults planning to enter college take CLEP exams, with approximately 2,900 accredited educational institutions currently accepting CLEP credits.
+       </p>
+ 
+       <h1>CLEP Major Subjects and Credit Examples</h1>
+ 
+       <table>
+         <thead>
+           <tr>
+             <th><strong>Subject</strong></th>
+             <th><strong>Exam Content</strong></th>
+             <th><strong>Credits</strong></th>
+           </tr>
+         </thead>
+         <tbody>
+           <tr>
+             <td>College Algebra</td>
+             <td>Basic concepts and calculations in algebra</td>
+             <td>3 credits</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>College Composition</td>
+             <td>Writing skills, grammar, and essay writing assessment</td>
+             <td>6 credits</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>Principles of Management</td>
+             <td>Basic management concepts and theories</td>
+             <td>3 credits</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>American History I</td>
+             <td>Early American history and major events analysis</td>
+             <td>3 credits</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>Biology</td>
+             <td>Biology concepts and scientific thinking</td>
+             <td>6 credits</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>Spanish Language</td>
+             <td>Spanish reading, listening, and grammar</td>
+             <td>Up to 12 credits</td>
+           </tr>
+         </tbody>
+       </table>
+ 
+       <p>Internet-based CLEP exams typically take about 90 minutes, while the College Composition exam takes approximately 120 minutes.</p>
+ 
+       <h1>CLEP Exam Details</h1>
+ 
+       <table>
+         <thead>
+           <tr>
+             <th><strong>Item</strong></th>
+             <th><strong>Description</strong></th>
+           </tr>
+         </thead>
+         <tbody>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Exam Purpose</strong></td>
+             <td>Evaluate knowledge of college subjects to earn credits</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Administering Organization</strong></td>
+             <td>College Board</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Target Audience</strong></td>
+             <td>High school students, college students, military personnel - Those seeking to earn degrees quickly while saving time and money</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Number of Subjects</strong></td>
+             <td>34 subjects</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Exam Format</strong></td>
+             <td>Primarily multiple-choice questions - Some subjects include essays and writing tasks</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Exam Duration</strong></td>
+             <td>Approximately 90-120 minutes</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Scoring System</strong></td>
+             <td>- Score range: 20-80 points - Generally, 50 points or higher is considered passing</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Exam Fee</strong></td>
+             <td>$93 (as of 2024) + Test center fee (additional cost)</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Credits Awarded</strong></td>
+             <td>About 3-12 credits per subject (varies by institution policy)</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Test Locations</strong></td>
+             <td>Official CLEP test centers - Remote online testing available (protocol compliance required)</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Study Materials</strong></td>
+             <td>Official CLEP textbooks - CLEP Practice Tests - Learning resources on College Board website</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Subject Areas</strong></td>
+             <td>History and Social Sciences, Composition and Literature, Mathematics, Science, Business, Foreign Languages</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Pass Rate</strong></td>
+             <td>Average pass rate: about 70% - Varies by subject and preparation level</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>Benefits</strong></td>
+             <td>- Save tuition costs - Accelerate graduation - Enhance career flexibility and achievement - Free for military personnel</td>
+           </tr>
+         </tbody>
+       </table>
+     </div>
+   </template>
+ 
+   <template x-if="$store.language === 'ko'">
+     <div class="ko-content">
+       <p>
          CLEP는 College-Level Examination Program의 약자로, 미국의 대학 교육을 대체할 수 있는 시험입니다. 학생들이 대학 과정에 필요한 학문적 능력을 입증하고, 대학에서의 학점 취득을 도와줍니다. CLEP 시험을 통해 학생들은 시간을 절약하고 비용을 줄일 수 있습니다.
+       </p>
  
+       <p>
          1967년 10개의 시험을 처음 제공한 이후, 현재 34개 과목의 CLEP 시험이 실시되고 있습니다. 18세부터 22세의 학생들과 고등학교 졸업자, 대학에 입학하려는 성인들이 CLEP 시험에 응시하고 있으며, 현재 2,900여개의 인가받은 교육 기관이 CLEP 취득을 인정하고 있습니다.
- 
- # CLEP 주요 과목 예시 및 인정 학점
- 
- | **과목**                 | **시험 내용**                       | **학점**    |
- |--------------------------|--------------------------------------|-------------|
- | College Algebra          | 대수학의 기본 개념과 계산            | 3학점       |
- | College Composition      | 작문 기술, 문법 및 에세이 작성 평가   | 6학점       |
- | Principles of Management | 경영학 기본 개념 및 이론             | 3학점       |
- | American History I       | 초기 미국 역사와 주요 사건 분석      | 3학점       |
- | Biology                  | 생물학 개념 및 과학적 사고           | 6학점       |
- | Spanish Language         | 스페인어 읽기, 듣기, 문법            | 최대 12학점 |
- 
- 시험 구조대 인터넷 기반 CLEP 시험은 약 90분간 진행되며, College Composition 시험은 약 120분간 진행됩니다. 
- 
- # CLEP 시험 상세 정보
- 
- | **항목**            | **설명**                                                                                                                                 |
- |---------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
- | **시험 목적**        | 대학 과목에 대한 지식을 평가하여 학점을 취득 가능하게 함.                                                                                   |
- | **운영 기관**        | College Board                                                                                                                           |
- | **시험 대상**        | 고등학생, 대학생, 군인 등 - 시간과 비용을 절약해 학위를 빠르게 취득하고 싶은 사람.                                                              |
- | **과목 수**          | 34개 과목                                                                                                                               |
- | **시험 형식**        | 주로 객관식 문제 (Multiple-Choice) - 일부 과목은 에세이 및 작성 문제 포함.                                                                    |
- | **시험 시간**        | 약 90-120분                                                                                                                             |
- | **점수 체계**        | - 점수 범위: 20~80점 - 일반적으로 50점 이상이 합격으로 간주됨.                                                                            |
- | **시험 비용**        | $93 (2024 기준) + 테스트 센터 수수료 (추가 비용)                                                                                           |
- | **합격 시 학점 인정** | 과목당 약 3~12학점 (학교의 정책에 따라 다름)                                                                                               |
- | **시험 응시 가능 장소** | 공식 CLEP 테스트 센터 - 원격 온라인 시험 가능 (프로토콜 준수 필요).                                                                       |
- | **시험 준비 자료**    | 공식 CLEP 교재 - CLEP Practice Tests - College Board 웹사이트의 제공 학습 자료.                                                               |
- | **시험 과목 분야**    | 역사와 사회과학, 작문과 문학, 수학, 과학, 비즈니스, 외국어                                                                                   |
- | **합격률**           | 평균 합격률: 약 70% - 과목 및 준비 수준에 따라 다름.                                                                                         |
- | **장점**             | - 학비 절약 - 졸업 시기 단축 - 직업적 유연성 및 성과 증대 - 군인 대상 무료 제공.                                                    |
+       </p>
+ 
+       <h1>CLEP 주요 과목 예시 및 인정 학점</h1>
+ 
+       <table>
+         <thead>
+           <tr>
+             <th><strong>과목</strong></th>
+             <th><strong>시험 내용</strong></th>
+             <th><strong>학점</strong></th>
+           </tr>
+         </thead>
+         <tbody>
+           <tr>
+             <td>College Algebra</td>
+             <td>대수학의 기본 개념과 계산</td>
+             <td>3학점</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>College Composition</td>
+             <td>작문 기술, 문법 및 에세이 작성 평가</td>
+             <td>6학점</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>Principles of Management</td>
+             <td>경영학 기본 개념 및 이론</td>
+             <td>3학점</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>American History I</td>
+             <td>초기 미국 역사와 주요 사건 분석</td>
+             <td>3학점</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>Biology</td>
+             <td>생물학 개념 및 과학적 사고</td>
+             <td>6학점</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td>Spanish Language</td>
+             <td>스페인어 읽기, 듣기, 문법</td>
+             <td>최대 12학점</td>
+           </tr>
+         </tbody>
+       </table>
+ 
+       <p>인터넷 기반 CLEP 시험은 약 90분간 진행되며, College Composition 시험은 약 120분간 진행됩니다.</p>
+ 
+       <h1>CLEP 시험 상세 정보</h1>
+ 
+       <table>
+         <thead>
+           <tr>
+             <th><strong>항목</strong></th>
+             <th><strong>설명</strong></th>
+           </tr>
+         </thead>
+         <tbody>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>시험 목적</strong></td>
+             <td>대학 과목에 대한 지식을 평가하여 학점을 취득 가능하게 함</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>운영 기관</strong></td>
+             <td>College Board</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>시험 대상</strong></td>
+             <td>고등학생, 대학생, 군인 등 - 시간과 비용을 절약해 학위를 빠르게 취득하고 싶은 사람</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>과목 수</strong></td>
+             <td>34개 과목</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>시험 형식</strong></td>
+             <td>주로 객관식 문제 (Multiple-Choice) - 일부 과목은 에세이 및 작성 문제 포함</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>시험 시간</strong></td>
+             <td>약 90-120분</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>점수 체계</strong></td>
+             <td>- 점수 범위: 20~80점 - 일반적으로 50점 이상이 합격으로 간주됨</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>시험 비용</strong></td>
+             <td>$93 (2024 기준) + 테스트 센터 수수료 (추가 비용)</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>합격 시 학점 인정</strong></td>
+             <td>과목당 약 3~12학점 (학교의 정책에 따라 다름)</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>시험 응시 가능 장소</strong></td>
+             <td>공식 CLEP 테스트 센터 - 원격 온라인 시험 가능 (프로토콜 준수 필요)</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>시험 준비 자료</strong></td>
+             <td>공식 CLEP 교재 - CLEP Practice Tests - College Board 웹사이트의 제공 학습 자료</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>시험 과목 분야</strong></td>
+             <td>역사와 사회과학, 작문과 문학, 수학, 과학, 비즈니스, 외국어</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>합격률</strong></td>
+             <td>평균 합격률: 약 70% - 과목 및 준비 수준에 따라 다름</td>
+           </tr>
+           <tr>
+             <td><strong>장점</strong></td>
+             <td>- 학비 절약 - 졸업 시기 단축 - 직업적 유연성 및 성과 증대 - 군인 대상 무료 제공</td>
+           </tr>
+         </tbody>
+       </table>
+     </div>
+   </template>
+ </div>
  
  
```

---
name:
  en: "GRE vs. GMAT"
  ko: "GRE와 GMAT 비교"
dropdownDescription:
  en: "Compare GRE and GMAT exams to choose the right graduate school admission test for your academic goals"
  ko: "대학원 입학을 위한 GRE와 GMAT 시험의 차이점을 비교하여 목표에 맞는 시험을 선택하세요"
image: "@images/stock/gre-vs-gmat.png"
fullHeight: true
---

<div x-data>
  <template x-if="$store.language !== 'ko'">
    <div class="en-content">
      <h3>GMAT vs GRE Comparison</h3>

      <h4>1. Purpose and Usage</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Designed specifically for business school (MBA) admissions, evaluating leadership and business-related skills.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Used for a broader range of graduate programs (Masters and PhD), accepted in humanities, sciences, engineering, and social sciences.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>2. Test Fees</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Approximately $275, more expensive than GRE.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Approximately $220, relatively cheaper than GMAT.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>3. Score Validity</h4>
      <p>Both GMAT and GRE scores are valid for <strong>5 years</strong>.</p>

      <h4>4. Test Length and Format</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Total test time is about 3 hours 7 minutes, uses <strong>Computer Adaptive Test (CAT)</strong> format where questions adjust based on answers.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Total test time is about 3 hours 45 minutes, uses <strong>Section Adaptive Test</strong> format where section difficulty adjusts.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>5. Graduate School Preferences</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Most MBA programs require or prefer GMAT scores.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Suitable for various graduate programs and accepted by business schools.</li>
      </ul>
^

      <h4>6. Test Preparation Difficulty</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Quantitative section based on logical reasoning with complex problems.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Quantitative section relatively simpler, but verbal problems (Text Completion, Sentence Equivalence) can be challenging due to advanced vocabulary.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>7. Retake Policy</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>:
          <ul>
            <li>Maximum <strong>5 attempts</strong> within 12 months.</li>
            <li>Lifetime limit of <strong>8 attempts</strong>.</li>
          </ul>
        </li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>:
          <ul>
            <li>Can retake every <strong>21 days</strong>.</li>
            <li>No lifetime limit on attempts.</li>
          </ul>
        </li>
      </ul>

      <h4>8. Score Reporting</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Can submit only recent scores or select specific scores.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Offers <strong>ScoreSelect</strong> option to submit best scores from multiple attempts.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>9. Career Plans</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: Highly valued in business, finance, and consulting fields.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: Suitable for students pursuing careers in science, technology, arts beyond business.</li>
      </ul>
    </div>
  </template>

  <template x-if="$store.language === 'ko'">
    <div class="ko-content">
      <h3>GMAT vs GRE 비교</h3>

      <h4>1. 목적 및 활용</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 경영대학원(MBA) 입학에 초점을 맞추어 설계된 시험으로, 리더십 및 비즈니스 관련 기술을 평가함.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 더 넓은 범위의 대학원 과정(석사 및 박사) 입학을 목표로 하며, 인문학, 과학, 공학, 사회과학 등 다양한 분야에서 사용됨.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>2. 시험 비용</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 약 $275로 GRE보다 비쌈.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 약 $220로 GMAT보다 상대적으로 저렴함.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>3. 점수 유효기간</h4>
      <p>GMAT과 GRE 모두 <strong>점수 유효기간은 5년</strong>으로 동일함.</p>

      <h4>4. 시험 길이 및 형식</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 총 시험 시간은 약 3시간 7분, <strong>Computer Adaptive Test(CAT)</strong> 방식으로 진행되며, 답변에 따라 다음 문제가 조정됨.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 총 시험 시간은 약 3시간 45분, 섹션별 난이도가 조정되는 <strong>Section Adaptive Test</strong> 방식으로 진행됨.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>5. 대학원 입학에서의 선호도</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 대부분의 MBA 프로그램에서 GMAT 점수를 요구하거나 우선적으로 고려함.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: MBA 외에도 다양한 분야의 대학원 과정에 적합하며, 비즈니스 스쿨에서도 수용 가능.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>6. 시험 준비의 난이도</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 수리 부분은 논리적 추론을 기반으로 하며, 복잡한 문제들이 출제됨.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 수리 부분은 상대적으로 간단하지만, 언어적 문제(Text Completion, Sentence Equivalence 등)가 고난이도 단어를 포함하여 어려움을 줄 수 있음.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>7. 재시험 정책</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>:
          <ul>
            <li>12개월 동안 최대 <strong>5회 응시 가능</strong>.</li>
            <li>평생 최대 <strong>8회 응시 제한</strong>.</li>
          </ul>
        </li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>:
          <ul>
            <li><strong>21일 간격</strong>으로 응시 가능.</li>
            <li>응시 횟수에 제한 없음.</li>
          </ul>
        </li>
      </ul>

      <h4>8. 스코어 리포팅</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 최근 점수만 제출하거나 선택적으로 보고 가능.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 여러 시험 중 가장 좋은 점수를 선택적으로 제출할 수 있는 <strong>ScoreSelect</strong> 기능 제공.</li>
      </ul>

      <h4>9. 커리어 플랜</h4>
      <ul>
        <li><strong>GMAT</strong>: 비즈니스, 금융, 컨설팅과 같은 분야에서 높은 평가 가능.</li>
        <li><strong>GRE</strong>: 경영학 외에도 과학, 기술, 예술 분야로 진출하려는 학생들에게 적합.</li>
      </ul>
    </div>
  </template>
</div>

================
File: .specstory/history/2025-02-07_14-41-alpine-js-conditional-text-rendering-issue.md
================
## SpecStory

## Alpine.js Conditional Text Rendering Issue (2/7/2025, 2:41:45 PM)

_**User**_

I need to render link.label.ko or en based on the condition, but nothing is rendered

---

_**Assistant**_

The issue is that Alpine’s runtime expression (in your `x-text` attribute) doesn’t have access to the local `link` variable. When you write

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<a
  href={link.href}
  class="block text-base font-medium text-gray-900 hover:text-purple-600"
  x-text="$store.language === 'ko' ? `${link.label.ko}` : `${link.label.en}`"
>
</a>
```

the expression inside `x-text` tries to reference `link.label.ko` and `link.label.en` at runtime—but **Alpine does not “see” the server‑side variable `link`**. (This works in parts of your code where you directly output text because you embed the data in attributes that Alpine can later read.)

A common solution is to materialize the value into a custom data attribute so that the needed strings are already embedded in the DOM. Then, Alpine can read them using `$el.getAttribute(...)` and react to changes in `$store.language`.

For example, update your code to:

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
:a/components/shared/Header.astro
<a
  href={link.href}
  class="block text-base font-medium text-gray-900 hover:text-purple-600"
  data-label-ko={link.label.ko}
  data-label-en={link.label.en}
  x-text="$store.language === 'ko' ? $el.getAttribute('data-label-ko') : $el.getAttribute('data-label-en')"
>
</a>
```

### Explanation

- **Embedding Data:**  
  The `data-label-ko` and `data-label-en` attributes ensure that the translated text values (from the `link` object) are rendered into the HTML at build time.

- **Alpine Access:**  
  In the browser, Alpine evaluates the `x-text` expression. Now it reads the proper attribute (`data-label-ko` or `data-label-en`) using `$el.getAttribute(...)` based on the current `$store.language` value.

- **Reactive Updates:**  
  If `$store.language` changes, Alpine will update the text content accordingly.

This pattern is also used in other parts of your header code (for example, with the program names) and ensures that the dynamic language switch works as expected.

Feel free to let me know if you have any more questions!

---

_**User**_

why this one also not rendered?

---

_**Assistant**_

The issue here is very similar to the previous one: in the Alpine expression inside the `<span>`, you're directly accessing the server-side `link` variable. Because Alpine runs on the client, it doesn't have access to variables (such as `link.label.ko` or `link.label.en`) that exist only during the server render.

### What's Happening?

In your code you have:

```astro
<span x-data x-text="$store.language === 'ko' ? `${link.label.ko}` : `${link.label.en}`"></span>
```

Here, Alpine tries to resolve `link.label.ko` at runtime—but Alpine has no idea what `link` is since it’s not part of its reactive scope. As a result, nothing is rendered.

### How to Fix It

Embed the content as data attributes so that the values are already present in the HTML when it reaches the browser. Then let Alpine pick them up. For example:

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<span 
  data-label-ko={link.label.ko} 
  data-label-en={link.label.en}
  x-text="$store.language === 'ko'
          ? $el.getAttribute('data-label-ko')
          : $el.getAttribute('data-label-en')">
</span>
```

### Explanation

- **Data Attributes:**  
  The `data-label-ko` and `data-label-en` attributes are rendered by Astro at build time using the `link` data.

- **Alpine Access:**  
  At runtime, Alpine's `x-text` expression accesses these attributes via `$el.getAttribute(...)`, so it no longer depends on the non-existent `link` variable in the client.

- **Consistent Pattern:**  
  You've already used this pattern successfully in other parts of your header (for the links in the dropdown menus), so applying it to the `<span>` in the button will make it work correctly.

By adjusting your code to this pattern, Alpine will be able to correctly render the text based on `$store.language`.

---

_**User**_

on mobile screen i thin there is wrong logic added for styling we have dedicated mobile navbar menu please check

---

_**Assistant**_

The issue is that the desktop navigation container is being conditionally shown on mobile screens via the Alpine logic. You already have a dedicated mobile navbar (the element with `md:hidden`) so you don't want the desktop nav to toggle visibility on mobile.

### What’s Happening

Currently, the desktop nav container is defined like this:

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<div class="items-center justify-between w-full md:flex md:w-auto" id="navbar-sticky" x-show="mobileMenuOpen || window.innerWidth >= 768">
  <!-- Desktop Navigation Markup -->
</div>
```

Because of the `x-show="mobileMenuOpen || window.innerWidth >= 768"`, if you set `mobileMenuOpen` to `true` on mobile, this container becomes visible—even though on mobile you’re supposed to display the dedicated mobile menu (the one with `md:hidden`).

### Recommended Fix

Since Tailwind’s responsive classes (like `hidden` and `md:flex`) already control the visibility based on screen width, you can remove the dynamic check from the desktop nav container and rely solely on Tailwind classes. For example, update the desktop nav container to use:

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<div class="hidden md:flex items-center justify-between w-full md:w-auto" id="navbar-sticky">
  <!-- Desktop Navigation Markup -->
</div>
```

### Explanation

- **Desktop Nav (md and up):**  
  The class `hidden` hides the element by default on mobile, and `md:flex` makes it display as flex on medium and larger screens.

- **Mobile Nav:**  
  The dedicated mobile menu (with `md:hidden` and `x-show="mobileMenuOpen"`) will display only on mobile when toggled.

By removing the `mobileMenuOpen || window.innerWidth >= 768` logic from the desktop nav container and adding `hidden md:flex`, you ensure that:

- On mobile devices, only the dedicated mobile navbar is used.
- On desktop devices, only the desktop navbar is rendered.

### Updated Code Snippet

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<div class="hidden md:flex items-center justify-between w-full md:w-auto" id="navbar-sticky">
  <ul class="flex flex-col p-4 md:p-0 mt-4 font-medium border border-gray-100 rounded-lg bg-gray-50 md:flex-row md:space-x-8 md:mt-0 md:border-0 md:bg-white">
    {navigation.map((link) => (
      // ... existing nav items
    ))}
  </ul>
</div>
```
```

Using this updated code makes sure that your mobile screen uses only the dedicated mobile navbar and your desktop uses only the desktop navbar.

---

_**User**_

For the code present, we get this error:
```
Element implicitly has an 'any' type because expression of type 'any' can't be used to index type '{ en: { title: string; subtitle: string; paragraph1: string; paragraph2: string; }; ko: { title: string; subtitle: string; paragraph1: string; paragraph2: string; }; }'.
```
How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.

---

_**Assistant**_

You can resolve the error by explicitly typing the `lang` prop so that TypeScript knows it will only be either `'en'` or `'ko'`. For example, declare an interface for your props and cast `Astro.props` accordingly in the frontmatter:

```astro:src/components/about/AboutHero.astro
---
interface Props {
  lang: 'en' | 'ko'
}

const { lang } = Astro.props as Props

const content: Record<'en' | 'ko', { 
  title: string; 
  subtitle: string; 
  paragraph1: string; 
  paragraph2: string 
}> = {
  en: {
    title: "Why BagelEdu",
    subtitle: "To improve English skills, you need to engage in conversations with smart and sharp mentors on good topics, understand them, and work on correcting mistakes.",
    paragraph1: "Students at prestigious British and American universities are trained to logically persuade and structure their thoughts in any situation through intense discussions and persuasion with professors and peers. These tutors from top universities and Ivy League schools share their thoughts directly in English and teach how to create sophisticated expressions and logical sentences that are actually used.",
    paragraph2: "While many native speakers can help with English learning, we emphasize the importance of mentors who can go beyond everyday conversation to engage in business case analysis and in-depth discussions. Furthermore, beyond simple quantitative achievements in curricular and extracurricular activities, we provide customized career planning tailored to students' career aspirations, tendencies, and characteristics. Through this, we help students grow beyond being simply 'well-rounded' to become 'spiked' talents most preferred by universities."
  },
  ko: {
    title: "Why BagelEdu",
    subtitle: "영어 실력을 키우려면, 똑똑하고 예리한 멘토와 좋은 주제로 대화하고, 이해하고 틀린 부분을 고쳐 나가야 합니다.",
    paragraph1: "영∙미 명문대 학생들은 교수와 동료와의 치열한 토론과 설득의 환경 속에서 어떤 상황에서도 논리적으로 설득하고 생각을 구조화할 수 있는 능력을 훈련받습니다. 이러한 명문대 및 아이비리그 출신 튜터들은 영어로 직접 사고를 나누며, 실제로 쓰이는 고급 표현과 논리적인 문장을 만드는 방법을 가르칩니다.",
    paragraph2: "많은 원어민이 영어 학습을 도울 수 있지만, 우리는 단순히 일상 대화를 넘어 비즈니스 사례 분석과 깊이 있는 토론까지 함께할 수 있는 멘토의 중요성을 강조합니다. 또한, 교과 및 비교과 활동의 단순한 양적 성취를 넘어, 학생의 진로 희망과 성향, 특성에 맞춘 맞춤형 진로 설계를 제공합니다. 이를 통해 단순히 '균형 잡힌(well-rounded)' 학생을 넘어, 대학에서 가장 선호하는 '특화된(spiked)' 인재로 성장할 수 있도록 돕습니다."
  }
}
---
```

### Explanation

- **Typing the Props:**  
  Declaring an interface (`Props`) that includes `lang` as either `'en'` or `'ko'` informs TypeScript of the expected type.

- **Casting Astro.props:**  
  Using `const { lang } = Astro.props as Props` ensures that `lang` is correctly typed, preventing the error when using it to index the `content` object.

This concise fix should resolve the error you're seeing.

---

_**User**_

For the code present, we get this error:
```
Element implicitly has an 'any' type because expression of type 'any' can't be used to index type '{ en: { title: string; subtitle: string; paragraph1: string; paragraph2: string; }; ko: { title: string; subtitle: string; paragraph1: string; paragraph2: string; }; }'.
```
How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.

---

_**Assistant**_

You need to let TypeScript know that the index used for `content` is either `"en"` or `"ko"`. A concise fix is to type your `lang` prop accordingly. For example:

```astro:src/components/about/AboutHero.astro
---
interface Props {
  lang: 'en' | 'ko'
}

const { lang } = Astro.props as Props

const content: Record<'en' | 'ko', { 
  title: string; 
  subtitle: string; 
  paragraph1: string; 
  paragraph2: string 
}> = {
  en: {
    title: "Why BagelEdu",
    subtitle: "To improve English skills, you need to engage in conversations with smart and sharp mentors on good topics, understand them, and work on correcting mistakes.",
    paragraph1: "Students at prestigious British and American universities are trained to logically persuade and structure their thoughts in any situation through intense discussions and persuasion with professors and peers. These tutors from top universities and Ivy League schools share their thoughts directly in English and teach how to create sophisticated expressions and logical sentences that are actually used.",
    paragraph2: "While many native speakers can help with English learning, we emphasize the importance of mentors who can go beyond everyday conversation to engage in business case analysis and in-depth discussions. Furthermore, beyond simple quantitative achievements in curricular and extracurricular activities, we provide customized career planning tailored to students' career aspirations, tendencies, and characteristics. Through this, we help students grow beyond being simply 'well-rounded' to become 'spiked' talents most preferred by universities."
  },
  ko: {
    title: "Why BagelEdu",
    subtitle: "영어 실력을 키우려면, 똑똑하고 예리한 멘토와 좋은 주제로 대화하고, 이해하고 틀린 부분을 고쳐 나가야 합니다.",
    paragraph1: "영∙미 명문대 학생들은 교수와 동료와의 치열한 토론과 설득의 환경 속에서 어떤 상황에서도 논리적으로 설득하고 생각을 구조화할 수 있는 능력을 훈련받습니다. 이러한 명문대 및 아이비리그 출신 튜터들은 영어로 직접 사고를 나누며, 실제로 쓰이는 고급 표현과 논리적인 문장을 만드는 방법을 가르칩니다.",
    paragraph2: "많은 원어민이 영어 학습을 도울 수 있지만, 우리는 단순히 일상 대화를 넘어 비즈니스 사례 분석과 깊이 있는 토론까지 함께할 수 있는 멘토의 중요성을 강조합니다. 또한, 교과 및 비교과 활동의 단순한 양적 성취를 넘어, 학생의 진로 희망과 성향, 특성에 맞춘 맞춤형 진로 설계를 제공합니다. 이를 통해 단순히 '균형 잡힌(well-rounded)' 학생을 넘어, 대학에서 가장 선호하는 '특화된(spiked)' 인재로 성장할 수 있도록 돕습니다."
  }
}
---
```

### Explanation

- **Typing the Prop:**  
  By declaring an interface for your props (`Props`) with `lang` as `'en' | 'ko'` (or using `keyof typeof content`), TypeScript knows the exact type of `lang`.  
- **Indexing Safely:**  
  Now using `content[lang]` is safe because TypeScript understands that `lang` is one of the keys defined in `content`.

This concise adjustment resolves the error.

---

_**User**_

For the code present, we get this error:
```
Argument of type '(pkg: PricingPackage) => any' is not assignable to parameter of type '(value: { title: { ko: string; en: string; }; description: { ko: string; en: string; }; duration: { ko: string; en: string; }; price: { ko: string; en: string; }; }, index: number, array: { title: { ko: string; en: string; }; description: { ...; }; duration: { ...; }; price: { ...; }; }[]) => any'.
  Types of parameters 'pkg' and 'value' are incompatible.
```
How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.

---

_**Assistant**_

The error occurs because your declared interface doesn't match the actual shape of data from `pricingSection.packages`. The data actually has localized fields (objects with `ko` and `en` strings) rather than simple strings.

A concise fix is to update your `PricingPackage` interface to match the data shape. For example:

```astro:src/components/programs/ProgramPricing.astro
---
interface LocalizedField {
  ko: string;
  en: string;
}

interface PricingPackage {
  title: LocalizedField;
  description: LocalizedField;
  price: LocalizedField;
  duration: LocalizedField;
}

const { program } = Astro.props;
const pricingSection = program.data.pricingSection;

if (!pricingSection) {
  return null;
}
---
```

Then, when rendering content, select the appropriate language (e.g., using Alpine or directly in the template):

```astro:src/components/programs/ProgramPricing.astro
{pricingSection.packages.map((pkg: PricingPackage) => (
  <div class="relative flex flex-col rounded-2xl bg-white border border-gray-100 hover:border-purple-100 transition-all duration-300 hover:shadow-xl group">
    <div class="absolute inset-0 rounded-2xl bg-gradient-to-b from-purple-50/50 to-white opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-opacity duration-300"></div>
    <div class="relative flex-1 p-8">
      <div class="flex items-center space-x-4">
        <h3 x-text="$store.language === 'ko' ? pkg.title.ko : pkg.title.en" class="text-2xl font-bold text-gray-900"></h3>
      </div>
      <!-- Other content -->
    </div>
  </div>
))}
```

### Explanation

- **Interface Update:**  
  The `LocalizedField` type represents an object with `ko` and `en` strings. Now each property in `PricingPackage` correctly reflects the localized data structure.

- **Rendering:**  
  When you render the package, choose the appropriate language key (`pkg.title.ko` or `pkg.title.en`) based on `$store.language`.

This concise change resolves the type error and ensures your data is correctly rendered.

---

_**User**_

For the code present, we get this error:
```
Type '{ en: string; }' is not assignable to type 'string'.
```
How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.

---

_**Assistant**_

The error occurs because the `Layout` component’s `title` and `description` props are expected to be simple strings, but you’re passing an object (with an `en` key) instead.

You have two concise fixes:

---

### **Option 1: Pass a String Instead**

If the `Layout` component is only meant to receive a string for these props, simply change your usage to pass a string:

```astro:src/pages/contact.astro
<Layout
  title={`Contact us - ${SITE.title}`}
  description="Get in touch with Bright Preschool & Elementary - we're here to help! Find our contact information, location, and hours, or submit an inquiry."
>
```

---

### **Option 2: Update Layout's Prop Types to Accept Localized Objects**

If you intend to support multiple languages (e.g., `en` and `ko`), update the `Layout` component’s prop types to accept an object. For example, in your `Layout.astro` file, change the frontmatter like so:

```astro:src/layouts/Layout.astro
---
interface Props {
  title: { en: string; ko?: string };
  description: { en: string; ko?: string };
  // Other props...
}

const { title, description } = Astro.props as Props;

// Use your localized values, e.g.,
// <h1>{ $store.language === 'ko' ? title.ko : title.en }</h1>
---
```

And then your calling code remains:

```astro:src/pages/contact.astro
<Layout
  title={{ en: `Contact us - ${SITE.title}` }}
  description={{ en: "Get in touch with Bright Preschool & Elementary - we're here to help! Find our contact information, location, and hours, or submit an inquiry." }}
>
```

---

Choose the option that best fits your design. Option 1 is the most straightforward if you don't need to handle multiple languages in `Layout`. Option 2 is the way to go if you want localization support.

================
File: .specstory/history/2025-02-07_14:41-alpine-js-conditional-text-rendering-issue.md
================
## SpecStory

## Alpine.js Conditional Text Rendering Issue (2/7/2025, 2:41:45 PM)

_**User**_

I need to render link.label.ko or en based on the condition, but nothing is rendered

---

_**Assistant**_

The issue is that Alpine’s runtime expression (in your `x-text` attribute) doesn’t have access to the local `link` variable. When you write

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<a
  href={link.href}
  class="block text-base font-medium text-gray-900 hover:text-purple-600"
  x-text="$store.language === 'ko' ? `${link.label.ko}` : `${link.label.en}`"
>
</a>
```

the expression inside `x-text` tries to reference `link.label.ko` and `link.label.en` at runtime—but **Alpine does not “see” the server‑side variable `link`**. (This works in parts of your code where you directly output text because you embed the data in attributes that Alpine can later read.)

A common solution is to materialize the value into a custom data attribute so that the needed strings are already embedded in the DOM. Then, Alpine can read them using `$el.getAttribute(...)` and react to changes in `$store.language`.

For example, update your code to:

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
:a/components/shared/Header.astro
<a
  href={link.href}
  class="block text-base font-medium text-gray-900 hover:text-purple-600"
  data-label-ko={link.label.ko}
  data-label-en={link.label.en}
  x-text="$store.language === 'ko' ? $el.getAttribute('data-label-ko') : $el.getAttribute('data-label-en')"
>
</a>
```

### Explanation

- **Embedding Data:**  
  The `data-label-ko` and `data-label-en` attributes ensure that the translated text values (from the `link` object) are rendered into the HTML at build time.

- **Alpine Access:**  
  In the browser, Alpine evaluates the `x-text` expression. Now it reads the proper attribute (`data-label-ko` or `data-label-en`) using `$el.getAttribute(...)` based on the current `$store.language` value.

- **Reactive Updates:**  
  If `$store.language` changes, Alpine will update the text content accordingly.

This pattern is also used in other parts of your header code (for example, with the program names) and ensures that the dynamic language switch works as expected.

Feel free to let me know if you have any more questions!

---

_**User**_

why this one also not rendered?

---

_**Assistant**_

The issue here is very similar to the previous one: in the Alpine expression inside the `<span>`, you're directly accessing the server-side `link` variable. Because Alpine runs on the client, it doesn't have access to variables (such as `link.label.ko` or `link.label.en`) that exist only during the server render.

### What's Happening?

In your code you have:

```astro
<span x-data x-text="$store.language === 'ko' ? `${link.label.ko}` : `${link.label.en}`"></span>
```

Here, Alpine tries to resolve `link.label.ko` at runtime—but Alpine has no idea what `link` is since it’s not part of its reactive scope. As a result, nothing is rendered.

### How to Fix It

Embed the content as data attributes so that the values are already present in the HTML when it reaches the browser. Then let Alpine pick them up. For example:

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<span 
  data-label-ko={link.label.ko} 
  data-label-en={link.label.en}
  x-text="$store.language === 'ko'
          ? $el.getAttribute('data-label-ko')
          : $el.getAttribute('data-label-en')">
</span>
```

### Explanation

- **Data Attributes:**  
  The `data-label-ko` and `data-label-en` attributes are rendered by Astro at build time using the `link` data.

- **Alpine Access:**  
  At runtime, Alpine's `x-text` expression accesses these attributes via `$el.getAttribute(...)`, so it no longer depends on the non-existent `link` variable in the client.

- **Consistent Pattern:**  
  You've already used this pattern successfully in other parts of your header (for the links in the dropdown menus), so applying it to the `<span>` in the button will make it work correctly.

By adjusting your code to this pattern, Alpine will be able to correctly render the text based on `$store.language`.

---

_**User**_

on mobile screen i thin there is wrong logic added for styling we have dedicated mobile navbar menu please check

---

_**Assistant**_

The issue is that the desktop navigation container is being conditionally shown on mobile screens via the Alpine logic. You already have a dedicated mobile navbar (the element with `md:hidden`) so you don't want the desktop nav to toggle visibility on mobile.

### What’s Happening

Currently, the desktop nav container is defined like this:

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<div class="items-center justify-between w-full md:flex md:w-auto" id="navbar-sticky" x-show="mobileMenuOpen || window.innerWidth >= 768">
  <!-- Desktop Navigation Markup -->
</div>
```

Because of the `x-show="mobileMenuOpen || window.innerWidth >= 768"`, if you set `mobileMenuOpen` to `true` on mobile, this container becomes visible—even though on mobile you’re supposed to display the dedicated mobile menu (the one with `md:hidden`).

### Recommended Fix

Since Tailwind’s responsive classes (like `hidden` and `md:flex`) already control the visibility based on screen width, you can remove the dynamic check from the desktop nav container and rely solely on Tailwind classes. For example, update the desktop nav container to use:

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<div class="hidden md:flex items-center justify-between w-full md:w-auto" id="navbar-sticky">
  <!-- Desktop Navigation Markup -->
</div>
```

### Explanation

- **Desktop Nav (md and up):**  
  The class `hidden` hides the element by default on mobile, and `md:flex` makes it display as flex on medium and larger screens.

- **Mobile Nav:**  
  The dedicated mobile menu (with `md:hidden` and `x-show="mobileMenuOpen"`) will display only on mobile when toggled.

By removing the `mobileMenuOpen || window.innerWidth >= 768` logic from the desktop nav container and adding `hidden md:flex`, you ensure that:

- On mobile devices, only the dedicated mobile navbar is used.
- On desktop devices, only the desktop navbar is rendered.

### Updated Code Snippet

```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
```astro:src/components/shared/Header.astro
<div class="hidden md:flex items-center justify-between w-full md:w-auto" id="navbar-sticky">
  <ul class="flex flex-col p-4 md:p-0 mt-4 font-medium border border-gray-100 rounded-lg bg-gray-50 md:flex-row md:space-x-8 md:mt-0 md:border-0 md:bg-white">
    {navigation.map((link) => (
      // ... existing nav items
    ))}
  </ul>
</div>
```
```

Using this updated code makes sure that your mobile screen uses only the dedicated mobile navbar and your desktop uses only the desktop navbar.

```

  subtitle: string; 
  paragraph1: string; 
  paragraph2: string 
}> = {
  en: {
    title: "Why BagelEdu",
    subtitle: "To improve English skills, you need to engage in conversations with smart and sharp mentors on good topics, understand them, and work on correcting mistakes.",
    paragraph1: "Students at prestigious British and American universities are trained to logically persuade and structure their thoughts in any situation through intense discussions and persuasion with professors and peers. These tutors from top universities and Ivy League schools share their thoughts directly in English and teach how to create sophisticated expressions and logical sentences that are actually used.",
    paragraph2: "While many native speakers can help with English learning, we emphasize the importance of mentors who can go beyond everyday conversation to engage in business case analysis and in-depth discussions. Furthermore, beyond simple quantitative achievements in curricular and extracurricular activities, we provide customized career planning tailored to students' career aspirations, tendencies, and characteristics. Through this, we help students grow beyond being simply 'well-rounded' to become 'spiked' talents most preferred by universities."
  },
  ko: {
    title: "Why BagelEdu",
    subtitle: "영어 실력을 키우려면, 똑똑하고 예리한 멘토와 좋은 주제로 대화하고, 이해하고 틀린 부분을 고쳐 나가야 합니다.",
    paragraph1: "영∙미 명문대 학생들은 교수와 동료와의 치열한 토론과 설득의 환경 속에서 어떤 상황에서도 논리적으로 설득하고 생각을 구조화할 수 있는 능력을 훈련받습니다. 이러한 명문대 및 아이비리그 출신 튜터들은 영어로 직접 사고를 나누며, 실제로 쓰이는 고급 표현과 논리적인 문장을 만드는 방법을 가르칩니다.",
    paragraph2: "많은 원어민이 영어 학습을 도울 수 있지만, 우리는 단순히 일상 대화를 넘어 비즈니스 사례 분석과 깊이 있는 토론까지 함께할 수 있는 멘토의 중요성을 강조합니다. 또한, 교과 및 비교과 활동의 단순한 양적 성취를 넘어, 학생의 진로 희망과 성향, 특성에 맞춘 맞춤형 진로 설계를 제공합니다. 이를 통해 단순히 '균형 잡힌(well-rounded)' 학생을 넘어, 대학에서 가장 선호하는 '특화된(spiked)' 인재로 성장할 수 있도록 돕습니다."
  }
}
---
```

### Explanation

- **Typing the Props:**  
  Declaring an interface (`Props`) that includes `lang` as either `'en'` or `'ko'` informs TypeScript of the expected type.

- **Casting Astro.props:**  
  Using `const { lang } = Astro.props as Props` ensures that `lang` is correctly typed, preventing the error when using it to index the `content` object.

This concise fix should resolve the error you're seeing.

---

_**User**_

For the code present, we get this error:
```
Element implicitly has an 'any' type because expression of type 'any' can't be used to index type '{ en: { title: string; subtitle: string; paragraph1: string; paragraph2: string; }; ko: { title: string; subtitle: string; paragraph1: string; paragraph2: string; }; }'.
```
How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.

---

_**Assistant**_

You need to let TypeScript know that the index used for `content` is either `"en"` or `"ko"`. A concise fix is to type your `lang` prop accordingly. For example:

```astro:src/components/about/AboutHero.astro
---
interface Props {
  lang: 'en' | 'ko'
}

const { lang } = Astro.props as Props

const content: Record<'en' | 'ko', { 
  title: string; 
  subtitle: string; 
  paragraph1: string; 
  paragraph2: string 
}> = {
  en: {
    title: "Why BagelEdu",
    subtitle: "To improve English skills, you need to engage in conversations with smart and sharp mentors on good topics, understand them, and work on correcting mistakes.",
    paragraph1: "Students at prestigious British and American universities are trained to logically persuade and structure their thoughts in any situation through intense discussions and persuasion with professors and peers. These tutors from top universities and Ivy League schools share their thoughts directly in English and teach how to create sophisticated expressions and logical sentences that are actually used.",
    paragraph2: "While many native speakers can help with English learning, we emphasize the importance of mentors who can go beyond everyday conversation to engage in business case analysis and in-depth discussions. Furthermore, beyond simple quantitative achievements in curricular and extracurricular activities, we provide customized career planning tailored to students' career aspirations, tendencies, and characteristics. Through this, we help students grow beyond being simply 'well-rounded' to become 'spiked' talents most preferred by universities."
  },
  ko: {
    title: "Why BagelEdu",
    subtitle: "영어 실력을 키우려면, 똑똑하고 예리한 멘토와 좋은 주제로 대화하고, 이해하고 틀린 부분을 고쳐 나가야 합니다.",
    paragraph1: "영∙미 명문대 학생들은 교수와 동료와의 치열한 토론과 설득의 환경 속에서 어떤 상황에서도 논리적으로 설득하고 생각을 구조화할 수 있는 능력을 훈련받습니다. 이러한 명문대 및 아이비리그 출신 튜터들은 영어로 직접 사고를 나누며, 실제로 쓰이는 고급 표현과 논리적인 문장을 만드는 방법을 가르칩니다.",
    paragraph2: "많은 원어민이 영어 학습을 도울 수 있지만, 우리는 단순히 일상 대화를 넘어 비즈니스 사례 분석과 깊이 있는 토론까지 함께할 수 있는 멘토의 중요성을 강조합니다. 또한, 교과 및 비교과 활동의 단순한 양적 성취를 넘어, 학생의 진로 희망과 성향, 특성에 맞춘 맞춤형 진로 설계를 제공합니다. 이를 통해 단순히 '균형 잡힌(well-rounded)' 학생을 넘어, 대학에서 가장 선호하는 '특화된(spiked)' 인재로 성장할 수 있도록 돕습니다."
  }
}
---
```

### Explanation

- **Typing the Prop:**  
  By declaring an interface for your props (`Props`) with `lang` as `'en' | 'ko'` (or using `keyof typeof content`), TypeScript knows the exact type of `lang`.  
- **Indexing Safely:**  
  Now using `content[lang]` is safe because TypeScript understands that `lang` is one of the keys defined in `content`.

This concise adjustment resolves the error.

---

_**User**_

For the code present, we get this error:
```
Argument of type '(pkg: PricingPackage) => any' is not assignable to parameter of type '(value: { title: { ko: string; en: string; }; description: { ko: string; en: string; }; duration: { ko: string; en: string; }; price: { ko: string; en: string; }; }, index: number, array: { title: { ko: string; en: string; }; description: { ...; }; duration: { ...; }; price: { ...; }; }[]) => any'.
  Types of parameters 'pkg' and 'value' are incompatible.
```
How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.

---

_**Assistant**_

The error occurs because your declared interface doesn't match the actual shape of data from `pricingSection.packages`. The data actually has localized fields (objects with `ko` and `en` strings) rather than simple strings.

A concise fix is to update your `PricingPackage` interface to match the data shape. For example:

```astro:src/components/programs/ProgramPricing.astro
---
interface LocalizedField {
  ko: string;
  en: string;
}

interface PricingPackage {
  title: LocalizedField;
  description: LocalizedField;
  price: LocalizedField;
  duration: LocalizedField;
}

const { program } = Astro.props;
const pricingSection = program.data.pricingSection;

if (!pricingSection) {
  return null;
}
---
```

Then, when rendering content, select the appropriate language (e.g., using Alpine or directly in the template):

```astro:src/components/programs/ProgramPricing.astro
{pricingSection.packages.map((pkg: PricingPackage) => (
  <div class="relative flex flex-col rounded-2xl bg-white border border-gray-100 hover:border-purple-100 transition-all duration-300 hover:shadow-xl group">
    <div class="absolute inset-0 rounded-2xl bg-gradient-to-b from-purple-50/50 to-white opacity-0 group-hover:opacity-100 transition-opacity duration-300"></div>
    <div class="relative flex-1 p-8">
      <div class="flex items-center space-x-4">
        <h3 x-text="$store.language === 'ko' ? pkg.title.ko : pkg.title.en" class="text-2xl font-bold text-gray-900"></h3>
      </div>
      <!-- Other content -->
    </div>
  </div>
))}
```

### Explanation

- **Interface Update:**  
  The `LocalizedField` type represents an object with `ko` and `en` strings. Now each property in `PricingPackage` correctly reflects the localized data structure.

- **Rendering:**  
  When you render the package, choose the appropriate language key (`pkg.title.ko` or `pkg.title.en`) based on `$store.language`.

This concise change resolves the type error and ensures your data is correctly rendered.

---

_**User**_

For the code present, we get this error:
```
Type '{ en: string; }' is not assignable to type 'string'.
```
How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.

---

_**Assistant**_

The error occurs because the `Layout` component’s `title` and `description` props are expected to be simple strings, but you’re passing an object (with an `en` key) instead.

You have two concise fixes:

---

### **Option 1: Pass a String Instead**

If the `Layout` component is only meant to receive a string for these props, simply change your usage to pass a string:

```astro:src/pages/contact.astro
<Layout
  title={`Contact us - ${SITE.title}`}
  description="Get in touch with Bright Preschool & Elementary - we're here to help! Find our contact information, location, and hours, or submit an inquiry."
>
```

---

### **Option 2: Update Layout's Prop Types to Accept Localized Objects**

If you intend to support multiple languages (e.g., `en` and `ko`), update the `Layout` component’s prop types to accept an object. For example, in your `Layout.astro` file, change the frontmatter like so:

```astro:src/layouts/Layout.astro
---
interface Props {
  title: { en: string; ko?: string };
  description: { en: string; ko?: string };
  // Other props...
}

const { title, description } = Astro.props as Props;

// Use your localized values, e.g.,
// <h1>{ $store.language === 'ko' ? title.ko : title.en }</h1>
---
```

And then your calling code remains:

```astro:src/pages/contact.astro
<Layout
  title={{ en: `Contact us - ${SITE.title}` }}
  description={{ en: "Get in touch with Bright Preschool & Elementary - we're here to help! Find our contact information, location, and hours, or submit an inquiry." }}
>
```

---

Choose the option that best fits your design. Option 1 is the most straightforward if you don't need to handle multiple languages in `Layout`. Option 2 is the way to go if you want localization support.

---

## SpecStory

## Keys to Standing Out in College Admissions (2/20/2025, 7:36:16 PM)

_**User**_

@planning-for-college-admission.mdx 

see the reference blog file 

here is the content below

Blog & News:[What Elite Colleges Really Look For in Applicants: The Keys to Standing Out]

Elite institutions such as Harvard, Stanford, and Princeton now have acceptance rates below 5%, making the admissions process incredibly competitive. This reality leads us to ask: What exactly do these schools seek in prospective students?
Simply achieving high grades and test scores is no longer sufficient; while academic excellence remains a fundamental requirement, elite colleges aim to assemble a well-rounded, diverse student body that enriches campus life and contributes meaningfully to society. Here’s what they value:
	1.	Intellectual Curiosity
Top-tier colleges seek applicants who possess a genuine passion for learning. It’s not just about enrolling in advanced courses—it’s about delving deeply into subjects that ignite curiosity. Whether through research, publishing, or pursuing unique academic endeavors, students need to show both enthusiasm and depth in their intellectual pursuits.
	2.	Impact
Admissions committees are impressed by students who make a tangible impact within their communities. It isn’t about holding numerous leadership positions; it’s about engaging deeply in a few activities and affecting real change. Whether leading a community service project, launching an innovative business, or excelling in the arts, these schools are looking for proactive individuals who create meaningful outcomes.
	3.	Authenticity
Authenticity is key. Admissions officers can easily discern when an application is overly polished or crafted merely to tick boxes. They want to understand what truly sets each student apart—their genuine motivations, values, and personal story. Encouraging applicants to reflect on what matters most to them, beyond their list of accomplishments, is crucial to presenting an honest and compelling narrative.
In summary, elite colleges are in search of students who will bring distinct qualities to their campus communities—students driven by purpose, authenticity, and a commitment to personal growth. By emphasizing depth over breadth and encouraging students to pursue their genuine interests, you help them craft an application that truly stands out in this highly competitive landscape.


---

_**Assistant**_

I'll help you add this content to the blog post. I'll first read the existing file structure and then make the appropriate edits.

Let me create a new blog post with the provided content while maintaining the same structure as the reference file.

+   특별하게 만드는 것이 무엇인지—그들의 진정한 동기, 가치관, 개인적인 이야기를

+   </p>

_**User**_

Collaborative Academic Goal-Setting for college admission in 2025

Collaboratively setting academic goals with your high school student can profoundly impact their educational journey. By partnering in this process, you help your teen establish a clear vision for their future, maintain motivation, and ultimately realize their aspirations. Here’s a step-by-step guide on how to approach this essential task:
Review Past Experiences
Start by evaluating your student’s previous academic performance. Discuss their proudest achievements and identify areas that posed challenges. This reflection not only offers valuable insights but also serves as a solid foundation for setting future goals.
Introduce SMART Goals
Guide your student towards establishing SMART goals—Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. This method ensures clarity and feasibility. For instance, rather than a vague aim to “get better at math,” a SMART goal would be “improve my math grade from a B to an A by the end of the semester.”
Collaborate Actively and Listen
Engage in meaningful conversations about your student’s interests, strengths, and future ambitions. Allow them to lead the goal-setting process while you provide thoughtful guidance and support. This cooperative approach cultivates a sense of ownership and drives intrinsic motivation.
Segment Goals into Manageable Steps
Help break down larger ambitions into smaller, actionable tasks. This strategy transforms overwhelming objectives into a clear, step-by-step roadmap. For example, if the goal is to enhance writing skills, consider actionable steps such as daily writing practice, soliciting feedback from teachers, or participating in a writing workshop.
Monitor and Adjust Regularly
Establish a routine for reviewing progress towards set goals. Celebrate milestones and address any challenges along the way. Flexibility is key—be prepared to adjust objectives to better align with your student’s evolving needs and circumstances.
Promote a Balanced Approach
While academic achievement is vital, it’s equally important to maintain a healthy balance with extracurricular activities, social life, and personal well-being. Encourage your student to pursue goals in diverse areas to ensure a well-rounded development.
Model the Behavior
Demonstrate goal-setting in your own life. Sharing your experiences, challenges, and successes can serve as a powerful example for your student to emulate.
By engaging directly in your student’s goal-setting process, you equip them with the tools and support needed for both academic and personal success. This collaborative approach not only enriches their educational experience but also strengthens your relationship as you work together towards common objectives.


ok make this one as well

**DO NOT CHANGE ORIGINAL CONTENT **

+ ---
+ title:
+   en: 'Collaborative Academic Goal-Setting for College Admission in 2025'
+   ko: '2025년 대학 입학을 위한 협력적 학업 목표 설정'
+ date: '2025-02-23'
+ author: 'Tina Sohn'
+ image:
+   src: '@images/bageledu/goal-setting.png'
+   alt: 'Academic Goal Setting'
+ excerpt:
+   en: 'Learn how to effectively partner with your high school student in setting and achieving academic goals for successful college admissions'
+   ko: '성공적인 대학 입학을 위해 고등학생 자녀와 함께 학업 목표를 설정하고 달성하는 효과적인 방법을 알아보세요'
+ category: 'College Planning'
+ authorImage: 'https://bageledu.sfo3.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com/hyejeong.jpg'
+ tags:
+   [
+     'Academic Goals',
+     'College Preparation',
+     'Parent Guidance',
+     'Student Success',
+   ]
+ ---
+ 
+ {/* English Content */}
+ 
+ <div class="en-content" x-show="$store.language !== 'ko'">
+   <h1>Collaborative Academic Goal-Setting for College Admission in 2025</h1>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <p>
+   Collaboratively setting academic goals with your high school student can
+   profoundly impact their educational journey. By partnering in this process,
+   you help your teen establish a clear vision for their future, maintain
+   motivation, and ultimately realize their aspirations. Here's a step-by-step
+   guide on how to approach this essential task:
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>Review Past Experiences</h2>
+ <p>
+   Start by evaluating your student's previous academic performance. Discuss
+   their proudest achievements and identify areas that posed challenges. This
+   reflection not only offers valuable insights but also serves as a solid
+   foundation for setting future goals.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>Introduce SMART Goals</h2>
+ <p>
+   Guide your student towards establishing SMART goals—Specific, Measurable,
+   Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. This method ensures clarity and
+   feasibility. For instance, rather than a vague aim to "get better at math," a
+   SMART goal would be "improve my math grade from a B to an A by the end of the
+   semester."
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>Collaborate Actively and Listen</h2>
+ <p>
+   Engage in meaningful conversations about your student's interests, strengths,
+   and future ambitions. Allow them to lead the goal-setting process while you
+   provide thoughtful guidance and support. This cooperative approach cultivates
+   a sense of ownership and drives intrinsic motivation.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>Segment Goals into Manageable Steps</h2>
+ <p>
+   Help break down larger ambitions into smaller, actionable tasks. This strategy
+   transforms overwhelming objectives into a clear, step-by-step roadmap. For
+   example, if the goal is to enhance writing skills, consider actionable steps
+   such as daily writing practice, soliciting feedback from teachers, or
+   participating in a writing workshop.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>Monitor and Adjust Regularly</h2>
+ <p>
+   Establish a routine for reviewing progress towards set goals. Celebrate
+   milestones and address any challenges along the way. Flexibility is key—be
+   prepared to adjust objectives to better align with your student's evolving
+   needs and circumstances.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>Promote a Balanced Approach</h2>
+ <p>
+   While academic achievement is vital, it's equally important to maintain a
+   healthy balance with extracurricular activities, social life, and personal
+   well-being. Encourage your student to pursue goals in diverse areas to ensure
+   a well-rounded development.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>Model the Behavior</h2>
+ <p>
+   Demonstrate goal-setting in your own life. Sharing your experiences,
+   challenges, and successes can serve as a powerful example for your student to
+   emulate.
+ </p>
+ 
+   <p>
+     By engaging directly in your student's goal-setting process, you equip them with the tools and support needed for both academic and personal success. This collaborative approach not only enriches their educational experience but also strengthens your relationship as you work together towards common objectives.
+   </p>
+ </div>
+ 
+ {/* Korean Content */}
+ 
+ <div class="ko-content" x-show="$store.language === 'ko'">
+   <h1>2025년 대학 입학을 위한 협력적 학업 목표 설정</h1>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <p>
+   고등학생 자녀와 함께 학업 목표를 설정하는 것은 그들의 교육 여정에 깊은 영향을
+   미칠 수 있습니다. 이 과정에서 협력함으로써, 여러분은 자녀가 미래에 대한 명확한
+   비전을 수립하고, 동기를 유지하며, 궁극적으로 그들의 열망을 실현하도록 도울 수
+   있습니다. 다음은 이 중요한 과제에 접근하는 단계별 가이드입니다:
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>과거 경험 검토하기</h2>
+ <p>
+   학생의 이전 학업 성과를 평가하는 것으로 시작하세요. 가장 자랑스러운 성취와
+   도전이 되었던 영역에 대해 논의하세요. 이러한 성찰은 귀중한 통찰을 제공할 뿐만
+   아니라, 미래 목표 설정을 위한 탄탄한 기반이 됩니다.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>SMART 목표 소개하기</h2>
+ <p>
+   학생이 SMART 목표—구체적(Specific), 측정 가능한(Measurable), 달성
+   가능한(Achievable), 관련성 있는(Relevant), 기한이 있는(Time-bound) 목표를
+   설정하도록 안내하세요. 이 방법은 명확성과 실현 가능성을 보장합니다. 예를 들어,
+   "수학을 잘하기"라는 모호한 목표 대신, "이번 학기 말까지 수학 성적을 B에서 A로
+   향상시키기"와 같은 SMART 목표를 설정하세요.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>적극적으로 협력하고 경청하기</h2>
+ <p>
+   학생의 관심사, 강점, 미래의 포부에 대해 의미 있는 대화를 나누세요. 여러분이
+   사려 깊은 지도와 지원을 제공하면서 학생이 목표 설정 과정을 주도하도록 하세요.
+   이러한 협력적 접근은 주인의식을 키우고 내적 동기를 촉진합니다.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>목표를 관리 가능한 단계로 나누기</h2>
+ <p>
+   큰 포부를 작고 실행 가능한 과제로 나누는 것을 도와주세요. 이 전략은 부담스러운
+   목표를 명확한 단계별 로드맵으로 변환합니다. 예를 들어, 글쓰기 실력 향상이
+   목표라면, 매일 글쓰기 연습, 교사로부터 피드백 받기, 글쓰기 워크숍 참여하기와
+   같은 실행 가능한 단계를 고려해보세요.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>정기적으로 모니터링하고 조정하기</h2>
+ <p>
+   설정된 목표를 향한 진행 상황을 검토하는 루틴을 수립하세요. 중간 성과를
+   축하하고 과정에서 발생하는 어려움에 대처하세요. 유연성이 핵심입니다—학생의
+   변화하는 필요와 상황에 맞춰 목표를 조정할 준비를 하세요.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>균형 잡힌 접근 방식 장려하기</h2>
+ <p>
+   학업 성취도 중요하지만, 과외 활동, 사회생활, 개인의 웰빙과 건강한 균형을
+   유지하는 것도 똑같이 중요합니다. 균형 잡힌 발전을 위해 학생이 다양한 영역에서
+   목표를 추구하도록 격려하세요.
+ </p>
+ 
+ {' '}
+ <h2>행동으로 보여주기</h2>
+ <p>
+   여러분의 삶에서 목표 설정을 실천하세요. 여러분의 경험, 도전, 성공을 공유하는
+   것은 학생이 본받을 수 있는 강력한 예시가 될 수 있습니다.
+ </p>
+ 
+   <p>
+     학생의 목표 설정 과정에 직접 참여함으로써, 여러분은 그들에게 학업과 개인적 성공에 필요한 도구와 지원을 제공합니다. 이러한 협력적 접근은 교육 경험을 풍부하게 할 뿐만 아니라, 공동의 목표를 향해 함께 노력하면서 여러분의 관계도 강화합니다.
+   </p>
+ </div>
+ 
```

I've created a new blog post file `collaborative-academic-goal-setting.mdx` with both English and Korean content. The file includes:

_**User**_

Empowering Young Innovators: A parent’s Guide to STEM Exploration in High School

Parents play a critical role in nurturing your child’s passion for science and technology during their high school years. Below is a guide designed to help support your high schooler as they explore the dynamic fields of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics):
Fostering Scientific Curiosity
Science is fundamentally about inquiry and exploration. Encourage your child to delve into various scientific disciplines—biology, chemistry, physics, earth sciences, and more. Engage in activities such as science fairs, school science clubs, or even simple home experiments to spark their curiosity and instill a lifelong love of discovery.
Exploring the World of Technology
With technology rapidly transforming our daily lives, high schoolers have ample opportunities to immerse themselves in this field. Whether it’s learning to code, joining robotics clubs, or participating in tech workshops, these experiences can provide practical skills. Additionally, online courses in web development, app creation, and related areas offer hands-on learning that may pave the way for future opportunities.
Participating in Competitions and Hackathons
Competitions and hackathons serve as excellent platforms for applying theoretical knowledge to real-world problems. Such events not only enhance technical abilities but also build crucial skills in teamwork, problem-solving, and communication.
Seeking Mentorship and Internship Opportunities
Connecting with professionals in science and technology can provide your child with valuable insights and guidance. Look for mentorship or internship opportunities through local tech companies, universities, or research institutions. This real-world exposure can help illuminate potential career paths and keep them informed about the latest advancements in these fields.
Staying Updated with Current Trends
The fields of science and technology are continuously evolving. To remain well-informed, follow relevant news sources, subscribe to science and tech magazines, or attend seminars and lectures. Continuous learning ensures your child stays abreast of new trends and innovations.
By actively encouraging your high schooler to explore science and technology, you’re opening doors to future academic and career opportunities while nurturing critical thinking and innovation. Embrace this exciting journey together, and let curiosity be the guiding force in their exploration of the STEM world.

make this one as well

_**Assistant**_

I'll create a new blog post with this content while maintaining the same bilingual format as the previous posts.

+ ---
+ title:
+   en: "Empowering Young Innovators: A Parent's Guide to STEM Exploration in High School"
+   ko: '젊은 혁신가 양성하기: 고등학교 STEM 탐구를 위한 학부모 가이드'
+ date: '2025-02-24'
+ author: 'Tina Sohn'
+ image:
+   src: '@images/bageledu/stem-education.png'
+   alt: 'STEM Education'
+ excerpt:
+   en: 'Guide parents in nurturing their high school students passion for science and technology through practical activities and meaningful engagement'
+   ko: '실용적인 활동과 의미 있는 참여를 통해 고등학생 자녀의 과학 기술 분야에 대한 열정을 키우는 방법을 안내합니다'
+ category: 'STEM Education'
+ authorImage: 'https://bageledu.sfo3.cdn.digitaloceanspaces.com/hyejeong.jpg'
+ tags: ['STEM Education', 'Science', 'Technology', 'Innovation', 'Parent Guide']
